batch-trigger-v1.description: \n Configuration deployed in batch-trigger-v1 configMap and loaded by batch-trigger service

backoff.title: initial backoff between 2 attempts for consumer offset cleanup

max-attempts.title: maximum number of attempts for consumer offset cleanup

consumer-offset-cleanup.title: consumer offset cleanup
consumer-offset-cleanup.description: \n Each batch creates its own consumer group when it starts consuming from Kafka topics. When batch completes in SUCCESS or FAILURE status, it cleans its consumer offsets in Kafka. This prevents detection of consumer lag for completed batches.

criticality.title: Batch criticality in a batch plan

threshold-max-number.title: Maximum number of failed operations in batch before it is marked as failed

threshold-max-percentage.title: Maximum percentage of failed operations vs processed operations in batch before it is marked as failed

threshold-min-operations.title: Minimum number of processed operations before percentage threshold is considered

failed-operations-log-limit.title: limit the maximum number of Failed Operations for which information is logged against each distinct error code encountered in the list of failed operations

application-service-code.title: value for header applicationServiceCode in batch-trigger topic

name.title: Name of batch
name.description: \n

operation-retention-time.title: retention time of batch operations in MongoDB
operation-retention-time.description: \n Operations must be persisted in database to ensure idempotence of consumer for topic batch-operation-processed. Retention time should be sufficient to allow restarting consumption of messages from a new pod when pod has crashed.

parameters.title: optional map of parameters sent with batch trigger message
parameters.description: \n Key for parameters can be any String and value must be a String.

plan-path.title: Path to the batch in a batch plan

production-delay.title: delay between topics consumption and production of batch trigger message
production-delay.description: \n Delay is required to ensure that consumers connect to Kafka before trigger message is produced. It is only applied when batch is started, not when it is resumed after timeout or pod failure.

rosa.description: Configuration options specific to Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA).

serviceMesh.description: Configuration options for enabling or disabling Service Mesh in ROSA.

enabled.description: Flag to enable or disable Service Mesh in ROSA.

job.title: Job.
job.description: \n To automate some processes like dataset initialization.

initDataSet.title: Dataset Initialization.
initDataSet.description: \n To have a reliable way to initialize dataset data in production for testing purpose.

enabled.title: To enable dataset initialization.
enabled.description: \n To define if dataset initialization will be enabled or not. By default set to `false`

image.title: Docker image.
image.description: \n In Docker vocabulary an image is a lightweight, stand-alone, executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software, including the code, a runtime, libraries, environment variables, and config files.

registry.title: Image registry.
registry.description: \n This defines the URL to the registry that store the application image (Default value: 461232396433.dkr.ecr.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com).

app.title: Application details.
app.description: \n To define details for application like apiVerstion, env, ports, dependencies, properties.

ports.title: Ports to access application.
ports.description: \n Port number is a way to identify a specific process to which an internet or other network message is to be forwarded when it arrives at a server.

api.title: API port.
api.description:
\n HTTP port the application listens to for API calls (as opposed to management port for probes).
\n Port on which API Gateway and the deployed APIs are available for consumption (Default value: 1080).

management.title: Management port.
management.description:
\n HTTP port the application listens to for probes.
\n Port is used to expose management/actuator endpoints to a different HTTP port other than the one used for running the application (Default value: 8080).

authorization.title: Authorization levels required for the application usage.
authorization.description:
\n Permissions and role mapping are required while working with new security annotations, in your microservice this mapping can be kept at externalized-conf.yml file, and in the environment it should be present at default-permissions-mapping.
\n
\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/security/abam/authentication/access-control/#authorization-validation-process-for-tokentype-annotations
authorization.x-intellij-html-description:
Permissions and role mapping are required while working with new security annotations, in your microservice this mapping can be kept at externalized-conf.yml file, and in the environment it should be present at default-permissions-mapping (Default value: default).

More information: App authorization

history.title: Revision history for kubernetes deployment.
history.description: \n History prints historical revisions for a given release.

limit.title: Revision history limit for kubernetes deployment.
limit.description: \n To limit the prints of historical revisions for a given release.

startupProbe.title: Startup probe to watch the health state of the application..
startupProbe.description:
\n To used to know when a container application has started.
\n
\n More information: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-liveness-readiness-startup-probes/ and https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/observability/kubernetes-way/health-check/
startupProbe.x-intellij-html-description:
To used to know when a container application has started.

More information: Startup Probe and Health Check

endPoint.title: End point for startup probe.
endPoint.description:
\n To implement functional checks in an application that external tools can access through exposed endpoints at regular intervals.
\n This can help to verify that applications and services are performing correctly (Default value: /actuator/healt/startup).

initialDelaySeconds.title: Initial delay seconds for startup probe.
initialDelaySeconds.description: \n Seconds to wait after the container has started (Default value: 10).

timeoutSeconds.title: Time out seconds for startup probe.

periodSeconds.title: Period seconds for startup probe.
periodSeconds.description: \n Wait time between probe executions (Default value: 5).

failureThreshold.title: Failure threshold for startup probe.
failureThreshold.description: \n Threshold needed to mark the container unhealthy (Default value: 20).

readinessProbe.title: Readiness probe to watch the health state of the application..
readinessProbe.description:
\n To used to know when a container is ready to start accepting traffic.
\n
\n More information: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-liveness-readiness-startup-probes/ and https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/observability/kubernetes-way/health-check/
readinessProbe.x-intellij-html-description:
To used to know when a container is ready to start accepting traffic.

More information: Startup Probe and Health Check

endPoint.title: End point for readiness probe.
endPoint.description:
\n To implement functional checks in an application that external tools can access through exposed endpoints at regular intervals.
\n This can help to verify that applications and services are performing correctly (Default value: /actuator/health/readiness).

timeoutSeconds.title: Time out seconds for readiness probe.

periodSeconds.title: Period seconds for readiness probe.
periodSeconds.description: \n Wait time between probe executions (Default value: 10).

failureThreshold.title: Failure threshold for readiness probe.
failureThreshold.description: \n Threshold needed to mark the container unhealthy (Default value: 3).

livenessProbe.title: Liveness probe to watch the health state of the application..
livenessProbe.description:
\n To used probes to know when to restart a container.
\n
\n More information: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-liveness-readiness-startup-probes/ and https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/observability/kubernetes-way/health-check/
livenessProbe.x-intellij-html-description:
To used probes to know when to restart a container.

More information: Startup Probe and Health Check

endPoint.title: End point for liveness probe.
endPoint.description:
\n To implement functional checks in an application that external tools can access through exposed endpoints at regular intervals.
\n This can help to verify that applications and services are performing correctly (Default value: /actuator/health/liveness).

timeoutSeconds.title: Time out seconds for liveness probe.

periodSeconds.title: Period seconds for liveness probe.
periodSeconds.description: \n Wait time between probe executions (Default value: 10).

failureThreshold.title: Failure threshold for liveness probe.
failureThreshold.description: \n Threshold needed to mark the container unhealthy (Default value: 3).

autoscaling.title: Horizontal pod autoscaling.
autoscaling.description:
\n In order to satisfy the demand, it is possible to spread the load over several services automatically. For SBCP, the Kubernetes layer is used to manage the autoscaling of application.
\n Some recommendation for horizontal pod autoscaling: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/hpa/

enabled.title: To enable hpa.
enabled.description: \n To define if horizontal pod autoscaling will be enabled or not (Default value: true).

minReplicas.title: Minimum replicas for hpa.
minReplicas.description: \n Sets the minimum number of replicas for this Deployment (Default value: 1).

maxReplicas.title: Maximum replicas for hpa.
maxReplicas.description: \n Sets the maximum number of replicas for this Deployment (Default value: 20).

cpuPercentage.title: Cpu percentage in each pod for hpa.
cpuPercentage.description: \n Target utilization value is set so that the controller calculates the utilization value as a percentage of the equivalent resource request on the containers in each Pod (Default value: 80).

behavior.title: Scale down or scale up behavior for hpa.
behavior.description: \n To define properties for hpa behaviour like scaledown, scaleup.

scaleDown.title: Scale down to reduce resources for hpa.
scaleDown.description: \n To define scale down behaviour as demand reduces for resources or traffic reduces.

stabilizationWindowSeconds.title: Scale down instabilities of resource usage for hpa.
stabilizationWindowSeconds.description:
\n Sometimes, a process can quickly switch between big load and low load.
\n In such a case, the HPA would adapt the sizing of the application too frequently, bringing a new layer of instabilities.
\n In order to avoid that, the field stabilizationWindowSeconds can be used.
\n For scale down, it will keep the highest scale calculation from the interval to scale the application (Default value: 850).
\n
\n More Information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/development-guide/hpa/recommendations#instabilities-of-resource-usage

policies.title: Scale down policies for hpa.
policies.description:
\n In order to prevent the HPA from starting additional pods at that time, the periodSeconds field of the scaling policy should be used.
\n This field is the period of time that the HPA calculate a number of pod to scale.
\n The value corresponds approximately to the application startup time.

type.title: Scale down policy type for hpa.
type.description: \n To define HPA scale down policy type e.g. Percent, Pods.

value.title: Scale down policy value for hpa.
value.description: \n To define HPA scale down policy value.

periodSeconds.title: Period seconds for hpa scale down policy .
periodSeconds.description:
\n The periodSeconds corresponds to the computation of the number of nodes.
\n And the stabilizationWindowSeconds compare each result of periodSeconds and find the min or max of the results value list (depending of scale  up: min value) or scale  down: max value)).
\n If there are not enough calculation steps during the windows, the result may be wrong.

scaleUp.title: HPA scale up to increase resources.
scaleUp.description: \n To define scale up behaviour as demand increases for resources or traffic increases.

stabilizationWindowSeconds.title: Scale up instabilities of resource usage for hpa.
stabilizationWindowSeconds.description:
\n Sometimes, a process can quickly switch between big load and low load.
\n In such a case, the HPA would adapt the sizing of the application too frequently, bringing a new layer of instabilities.
\n In order to avoid that, the field stabilizationWindowSeconds can be used.
\n For scale up, it will keep the lower scale calculation from the interval to scale the application (Default value: 300).
\n
\n More Information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/development-guide/hpa/recommendations#instabilities-of-resource-usage

policies.title: Scale up policies for hpa.
policies.description:
\n In order to prevent the HPA from starting additional pods at that time, the periodSeconds field of the scaling policy should be used.
\n This field is the period of time that the HPA calculate a number of pod to scale.
\n The value corresponds approximately to the application startup time.

type.title: Scale up policy type for hpa.
type.description: \n To define HPA scale up policy type e.g. Percent, Pods.

value.title: Scale up policy value for hpa.
value.description: \n To define HPA scale up policy value .

periodSeconds.title: Period seconds for hpa scale up policy.
periodSeconds.description:
\n The periodSeconds corresponds to the computation of the number of nodes.
\n And the stabilizationWindowSeconds compare each result of periodSeconds and find the min or max of the results value list (depending of scale  up: min value) or scale  down: max value)).
\n If there are not enough calculation steps during the windows, the result may be wrong.

selectPolicy.title: Select policy for hpa scale up.
selectPolicy.description: \n To define hpa scaleUp select policy.

operators.title: Database operators.
operators.description:
\n An operator is a reserved word or a character that is used to query our database in a SQL expression.
\n Operators are necessary to define a condition in SQL, as they act as a connector between two or more conditions.
\n Any given application SHALL NOT use more than one database for each database type (one in MongoDB + one in PostgreSQL).
\n Any given database SHALL NOT be used by more than one application.
\n
\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/database-management/
operators.x-intellij-html-description:
An operator is a reserved word or a character that is used to query our database in a SQL expression.
Operators are necessary to define a condition in SQL, as they act as a connector between two or more conditions.
Any given application SHALL NOT use more than one database for each database type (one in MongoDB + one in PostgreSQL).
Any given database SHALL NOT be used by more than one application.

More information: Database Management

dropDbOnDelete.title: Drop database on resource deletion
dropDbOnDelete.description:
Controls whether the PostgreSQL database should be automatically deleted from RDS when the Helm chart is uninstalled or the Postgres resource is removed. When set to true, uninstalling the application will permanently delete the associated database and all its data. When set to false (default), the database will be preserved even after the application is removed, allowing for data recovery or migration scenarios.

Warning: Setting this to true will result in permanent data loss upon uninstallation.

Default value: false

More information: https://docs.soprabanking.io/sbcp/latest/en/docs/development-guide/environment/postgres/
dropDbOnDelete.x-intellij-html-description:
Controls whether the PostgreSQL database should be automatically deleted from RDS when the Helm chart is uninstalled or the Postgres resource is removed.

When set to true, uninstalling the application will permanently delete the associated database and all its data. When set to false (default), the database will be preserved even after the application is removed, allowing for data recovery or migration scenarios.

Warning: Setting this to true will result in permanent data loss upon uninstallation.

Default value: false

More information: PostgreSQL Documentation

istio.title: Istio to handle external calls to HTTPS endpoints.
istio.description:
\n In SBCP, Istio is in charge of performing the TLS/mTLS origination and port rewriting.
\n Application pods must call a given host using plain HTTP on port 80.
\n
\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/development-guide/service-mesh/
istio.x-intellij-html-description:
In SBCP, Istio is in charge of performing the TLS/mTLS origination and port rewriting.
Application pods must call a given host using plain HTTP on port 80.

More information: Service mesh

retry.title: Retry policy for Istio.
retry.description:
\n Microservices architectures are distributed.
\n This means more requests on the network, increasing the chance of transient failures like network congestion.
\n Adding retry policies for requests helps build resiliency in a services architecture.
\n
\n More information: https://istio.io/docs/reference/config/networking/v1alpha3/virtual-service/#HTTPRetry
retry.x-intellij-html-description:
Microservices architectures are distributed.
This means more requests on the network, increasing the chance of transient failures like network congestion.
Adding retry policies for requests helps build resiliency in a services architecture.

More information: Istio Retry Policy

fromProxy.title: Retry policy coming from server-proxy.
fromProxy.description:
\n Microservices architectures are distributed.
\n This means more requests on the network, increasing the chance of transient failures like network congestion.
\n Adding retry policies for requests helps build resiliency in a services architecture.
\n This rule configures the istio retry if a request is coming from server-proxy. 
\n
\n More information: https://istio.io/docs/reference/config/networking/v1alpha3/virtual-service/#HTTPRetry
fromProxy.x-intellij-html-description:
Microservices architectures are distributed.
This means more requests on the network, increasing the chance of transient failures like network congestion.
Adding retry policies for requests helps build resiliency in a services architecture.
This rule configures the istio retry if a request is coming from server-proxy.

More information: Istio Retry Policy

enabled.title: To enable server-proxy Istio retry policy.
enabled.description: \n To define if Istio retryPolicy will be enabled or not for server-proxy (Default value: false).

attempts.title: Number of retries to be allowed for a given request.
attempts.description:
\n The interval between retries will be determined automatically (25ms+).
\n When request timeout of the HTTP route or per_try_timeout is configured, the actual number of retries attempted also depends on the specified request timeout and per_try_timeout values (Default retry value: 2). 
\n Attempts for Retry could also be set to 0(i.e. disabled). In this case, there would be a Virtual Service created with no retry.
\n Current behavior in dxp-spring helm chart was to completely disable the VirtualService, not the retries. If we disable the VS, (stop the creation of VS), global setting will be applied i,.e 2 retry.

app.description: \n To define details for application like apiVersion, env, ports, dependencies, properties.

name.title: Application name.
name.description: \n To define name of application.

group.title: Application group name.
group.description: \n To define group name of application.

apiVersion.title: Major version for api of an application.
apiVersion.description:
\n API version is appended to the microservice name for all generated resources (deployment, service, autoscaler ...).
\n It defaults to v1 and allows to handle breaking changes in API exposed by a microservice.
\n By deploying the new version of the microservice in parallel with the previous version (Default value: v1).
\n
\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/versioning/rest_api_versioning/. 
\n This property is marked as Deprecated from 2025.1 final release.

authorization.title: Authorization levels required for the application usage.
authorization.description:
\n Permissions and role mapping are required while working with new security annotations, in your microservice this mapping can be kept at externalized-conf.yml file, and in the environment it should be present at default-permissions-mapping (Default value: default).
\n
\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/security/abam/authentication/access-control/#authorization-validation-process-for-tokentype-annotations

logType.title: Describe the log format of the application.
logType.description:
\n Log type used as an informative label named log_type in created Kubernetes objects (deployment, service, job, HPA ...).
\n It is not mandatory and does not impact the log format of the application. (Default value: sbs).
\n
\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/observability/logs/#pattern

kind.title: The category of service provided by the application.
kind.description: \n kind used as an informative label in created Kubernetes objects (deployment, service, job, HPA ...). (Default value: unknown).

replicaCount.title: Define replica set to be running for application.
replicaCount.description:
\n ReplicaCount define the number of application Pods running at any given time.
\n ReplicaCount will always match the desired count with actual count for application running pods (Default value: 1).

pdb.title: Define Pod Disruption Budget for application.
pdb.description:
\n PodDisruptionBudget (PDB) is a policy that limits the number of pods that can be down simultaneously.
\n PDB is used to ensure that a specified number of pods are available at any given time during a disruption.

minAvailable.title: Minimum number of pods that must be available.
minAvailable.description: \n Minimum number of pods that must be available during a disruption (Default value: 0).

priorityClassName.title: Define priority class name for application.
priorityClassName.description: \n PriorityClassName is the name of the PriorityClass for this pod. If not specified, the pod priority will be default (sbcp-low-sla).

serviceaccount.title: Define service account to be bind with application.
serviceaccount.description: \n To enable service account that needs to be included for current application.

enabled.title: Is your application requires service account.
enabled.description: \n Used as an informative label to indicate that the application uses service account (Default value: false).

name.title: Name of the service account
name.description:
\n Used as an informative label to indicate the name of service account that application uses.
\n This property is marked as Deprecated from 2024.4 final release

provisionedResources.title: Provisioned Resources Configuration.
provisionedResources.description: \n A collection of infrastructure resources explicitly allocated for the application, including messaging, databases, storage, and other external dependencies.

kafka.title: Represents configurations specific to Kafka services.
kafka.description:
\n This specifies the configurations related to Kafka as a messaging service.
\n It would include properties to control Kafkas behavior, such as whether it is enabled, topic settings, etc. This structure allows flexibility in toggling Kafka functionality, enabling or disabling specific topics, and applying detailed settings at the topic level.

enabled.title: A flag to indicate whether Kafka service is enabled.
enabled.description: \n Indicates whether Kafka is provisioned for this application.

topics.title: Contains configurations for Kafka topics, represented as key-value pairs.
topics.description:
\n This specifies the configurations for Kafka topics, represented as key-value pairs.
\n The key is the topic name, and the value contains specific configurations for the topic.

enabled.title: A flag to indicate whether a specific topic is enabled.
enabled.description: \n Indicates whether this topic is required by the microservice.

config.title: Holds additional configurations specific to the topic.
config.description: \n Configuration details for the Kafka topic. This is optional if the microservice is not the topic owner.

retentionTime.title: Specifies how long Kafka retains the messages in the topic before they are deleted.
retentionTime.description:
\n This specifies how long Kafka retains the messages in the topic before they are deleted.
\n Typically defined in a time format like seconds, minutes, hours, or days (ms, s, m, h, or d).

partitions.title: The number of partitions the topic should have.
partitions.description: \n This specifies the number of partitions the topic should have. It determines the parallelism and scalability of the topic.

replicationFactor.title: Defines the number of replicas for each partition.
replicationFactor.description: \n This specifies the number of replicas for each partition, ensuring fault tolerance.

cleanupPolicy.title: Determines how Kafka handles data cleanup.
cleanupPolicy.description: \n The cleanup policy for the Kafka topic. Allowed values: 'DELETE' or 'COMPACT'. Default: DELETE.

exposition.title: Exposition configuration(mTLS), This object is optional in case the topic needs to be exposed to external users.
exposition.description: \n Exposition configuration(mTLS), This object is optional in case the topic needs to be exposed to external users.

enabled.title: A flag to indicate whether a mTLS is enabled.
enabled.description: \n A flag to indicate whether a mTLS is enabled.

users.description: List of users with their subjects and permissions.

subject.title: The subject of the user.
subject.description: By default, the name of the principal identified by a TLS certificate is the DN (X.500 Distinguished Name) of the certificate. Please refer to [TLS principal user name](https://docs.confluent.io/platform/current/security/authorization/acls/overview.html#tls-principal-user-name) documentation for more information.

permissions.title: List of permissions for the user.
permissions.description: List of permissions for the user.

items.title: The permissions assigned to the user.
items.description: The permissions assigned to the user.

ports.title: Ports to access application.
ports.description: \n Port number is a way to identify a specific process to which an internet or other network message is to be forwarded when it arrives at a server.

api.title: API port.
api.description:
\n HTTP port the application listens to for API calls (as opposed to management port for probes).
\n Port on which API Gateway and the deployed APIs are available for consumption (Default value: 1080).

management.title: Management port.
management.description:
\n HTTP port the application listens to for probes.
\n Port is used to expose management/actuator endpoints to a different HTTP port other than the one used for running the application (Default value: 8080).

env.title: Environment properties.
env.description:
\n Environment properties hold the user or system defined dependent variables.
\n It hold values for variables, extraConfigMaps.

vars.title: Environment variables.
vars.description:
\n Environment variable hold the user or system defined dependent variables that are required to run the micro service that run with in the application pod.
\n Env vars are easy to change between deploys without changing any code; unlike config files, there is little chance of them being checked into the code repo accidentally; and unlike custom config files, or other config mechanisms such as Java System Properties, they are a language and OS-agnostic standard.

extraConfigMaps.title: Additional config maps for environment.
extraConfigMaps.description:
\n ConfigMap is used to store non-confidential data in key-value pairs.
\n ConfigMap allows to decouple environment-specific configuration from your application pod, so that your applications are easily portable.

enabled.title: Enable creation of the additional config map.
enabled.description: \n Value should be true by default and can be set to false in parent charts to disable generation of the configMap.

optional.title: Enable requirement of the additional config map.
optional.description: \n The optional field specifies whether or not the presence of a ConfigMap is required for the deployment to succeed. If optional: true is set, the deployment will continue even if the ConfigMap is not available.

encrypted.title: Encryption for secrets at environment level.
encrypted.description:
\n Secrets MUST NOT be stored in source management system (likeGit).
\n  If secrets have to be stored in Git, an encryption mechanism must be put in place, and the decryption material must be stored in a separate place outside the Git project.

namespaceWide.title: To define encryption scope under namespace.
namespaceWide.description: \n Allows specifying whether the encryption scope of the SealedSecret-encrypted values is namespace-wide or not (Default value: true).

vars.title: Encryption vars.
vars.description:
\n Key-value pairs of environment variables to be made available to the micro-service, where the key is the env var name, and the value is the SealedSecret-encrypted value.
\n
\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/development-guide/environment/deploy-secret/
vars.x-intellij-html-description:
Key-value pairs of environment variables to be made available to the micro-service, where the key is the env var name, and the value is the SealedSecret-encrypted value.

More information: Deploy Secret

extraSecrets.title: Additional secrets map for encryption.
extraSecrets.description: \n Map of Secrets to load as env vars (any enclosing bundle can add additional secrets to the ones already defined within enclosed bundles).

enabled.title: Enable creation of the additional secrets.
enabled.description: \n Value should be true by default and can be set to false in parent charts to disable additional secrets.

optional.title: Enable requirement of the additional secrets.
optional.description: \n The optional field specifies whether or not the presence of a Secret is required for the deployment to succeed. If optional: true is set, the deployment will continue even if the Secret is not available.

properties.title: Application properties.
properties.description: \n To define application properties like content, extraConfigMaps.

content.title: Application content.
content.description:
\n Content of application-ps.yml.
\n This content should be defined as YAML content directly, but also works (for retro-compatibility) with multi-line strings.

extraConfigMaps.title: Additional config maps for application.
extraConfigMaps.description: \n Config Maps of Spring YAML properties to load in addition to application-ps.yml.

enabled.title: Enable creation of the config map.
enabled.description: \n Value should be true by default and can be set to false in parent charts to disable generation of the configMap.

optional.title: Enable requirement of the additional  config map.
optional.description: \n The optional field specifies whether or not the presence of a ConfigMap is required for the deployment to succeed. If optional: true is set, the deployment will continue even if the ConfigMap is not available.

encrypted.title: Encryption of secrets at application level.
encrypted.description:
\n Secrets MUST NOT be stored in source management system (likeGit).
\n  If secrets have to be stored in Git, an encryption mechanism must be put in place, and the decryption material must be stored in a separate place outside the Git project.

namespaceWide.title: Encryption scope under namespace.
namespaceWide.description: \n Allows specifying whether the encryption scope of the SealedSecret-encrypted values is namespace-wide or not (Default value: true).

contentValues.title: Encryption key value pair for content.
contentValues.description:
\n Key-value pairs with SealedSecret-encrypted values to be used in the "content" section.
\n That section (which contains YAML Spring properties) can then refer to those keys for mapping an encrypted value to a YAML property.

content.title: Content of application-secrets.yml.
content.description: \n This content should be defined as YAML content directly. The YAML leaf values can refer to the keys of the encrypted values defined in "contentValues".

extraSecrets.title: Additional secrets map for encryption.
extraSecrets.description:
\n Secrets containing Spring YAML properties to load in addition to application-ps.yml.
\n Such Secret resources must contain one key named <Secret-name>.yml, and its value must be the YAML content to load.

enabled.title: Enable creation of the additional secrets.
enabled.description: \n Value should be true by default and can be set to false in parent charts to disable additional secrets.

optional.title: Enable requirement of the additional  secrets.
optional.description: \n The optional field specifies whether or not the presence of a Secret is required for the deployment to succeed. If optional: true is set, the deployment will continue even if the Secret is not available.

retryStrategy.title: Retry Configuration for Handling retries after failures and errors
retryStrategy.description: \n The retryStrategy object defines the retry behavior, this allows to handle retries after failures and errors.

limit.title: Retry Limit.
limit.description: \n This specifies the maximum number of retries allowed for the operation

backoff.title: Retry Backoff.
backoff.description: \n This specifies the backoff strategy for retrying the operation

duration.title: Duration of the backoff
duration.description: \n This specifies the initial duration of the backoff period

factor.title: Factor of the backoff
factor.description: \n This specifies the factor by which the backoff duration increases after each retry.

maxDuration.title: Max Duration of the backoff
maxDuration.description: \n This specifies the maximum duration of the backoff period.

expression.title: Retry Expression.
expression.description: \n Specifies the expression that determines whether to retry the operation. If the expression evaluates to true, the operation will be retried.

affinity.title: Retry Affinity.
affinity.description: \n Specifies the affinity rules for retrying the operation.

retryPolicy.title: Retry Policy.
retryPolicy.description: \n Specifies the retry policy that will be used to determine when a retry should be attempted.

securityContext.title: Security context for the workflow.
securityContext.description: \n Specifies the security context for the workflow.

runAsUser.title: Run as user.
runAsUser.description: \n Specifies the user ID that runs the workflow.

runAsGroup.title: Run as group.
runAsGroup.description: \n Specifies the group ID that runs the workflow.

runAsNonRoot.title: Run as non root.
runAsNonRoot.description: \n Specifies whether the workflow runs as a non-root user.

readOnlyRootFilesystem.title: Read only root filesystem.
readOnlyRootFilesystem.description: \n Specifies whether the root filesystem is read-only.

privileged.title: Privileged.
privileged.description: \n Specifies whether the workflow runs in privileged mode.

capabilities.title: Capabilities.
capabilities.description: \n Specifies the capabilities for the workflow.

allowPrivilegeEscalation.title: Allow privilege escalation.
allowPrivilegeEscalation.description: \n Specifies whether privilege escalation is allowed.

useVersionedAppName.title: Use Versioned Application Name
useVersionedAppName.description: This configuration option determines whether to use a versioned application name. If set to true, the application name will include the API version as a suffix.

job.title: Job.
job.description: \n To automate some processes like dataset initialization.

initDataSet.title: Dataset initialization.
initDataSet.description: \n To have a reliable way to initialize dataset data in production for testing purpose.

properties.title: Dataset initialization properties.
properties.description: \n To define Dataset Initialization properties like extraConfigMaps.

extraConfigMaps.title: Extra config maps for dataset initialization.
extraConfigMaps.description:
\n Additional config Maps of Spring YAML properties to load in addition to application configMaps.
\n User need to include the name of the extraConfigMaps and set the property enabled as true.

enabled.title: Enable creation of the config map.
enabled.description: \n Value should be true by default and can be set to false in parent charts to disable generation of the configMap.

optional.title: Enable requirement of the additional  config map.
optional.description: \n The optional field specifies whether or not the presence of a ConfigMap is required for the deployment to succeed. If optional: true is set, the deployment will continue even if the ConfigMap is not available.

profiles.title: Dataset initialization spring profiles.
profiles.description: \n To define list of Spring profiles enabled for init-dataset job (Default value: mock_kafka,init_dataset).

restartPolicy.title: Dataset initialization restart policy for containers.
restartPolicy.description:
\n The restartPolicy applies to all containers in the Pod.
\n RestartPolicy only refers to restarts of the containers by the kubelet on the same node.
\n After containers in a Pod exit, the kubelet restarts them with an exponential back-off delay (10s, 20s, 40s, ), that is capped at five minutes (Default value: never).

backoffLimit.title: Backoff limit for dataset initialization.
backoffLimit.description: \n To specify the number of re-tries before job controller gives up.

ttlSecondsAfterFinished.title: TTL seconds after finished for dataset initialization.
ttlSecondsAfterFinished.description:
\n TTL-after-finished controller provides a TTL (time to live) mechanism to limit the lifetime of resource objects that have finished execution.
\n TTL controller only handles Jobs (Default value: 600).

activeDeadlineSeconds.title: Active Deadline Seconds.
activeDeadlineSeconds.description: \n Specifies the duration in seconds that the workflow is allowed to run before being forcefully terminated.

ttlStrategy.title: Time to live strategy for the workflow.
ttlStrategy.description:
Specifies the time-to-live (TTL) strategy for the workflow.

 The TTL strategy determines how long the workflow should be retained before it is automatically terminated.

secondsAfterCompletion.title: Seconds after completion.
secondsAfterCompletion.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after the workflow has completed before it is terminated.

secondsAfterFailure.title: Seconds after failure.
secondsAfterFailure.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after the workflow has failed before it is terminated.

secondsAfterSuccess.title: Seconds after Success.
secondsAfterSuccess.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after the workflow has succeeded before it is terminated.

workflow.title: Switch for Argo Workflow Deployment
workflow.description: \n Property to decide the Argo Workflow execution/deployment for the Dataset Initialization.

enabled.title: Enable/Disable the Argo Workflow execution for the Dataset Initialization.
enabled.description: \n Value should be set to false to disable Argo Workflow execution for the Dataset Initialization. By default set to true.

outputs.title: Outputs for init-dataset job
outputs.description: To define the `outputs` property of the init-dataset job.

artifacts.title: Artifacts for init-dataset job
artifacts.description: To define the artifacts generated by Argo init-dataset, which is to be uploaded to AWS S3 Bucket

name.title: Name of the artifact
name.description: Name of the artifact generated by Argo init-dataset

path.title: Path of the artifact
path.description: Path of the artifact generated by Argo init-dataset

image.title: Docker image.
image.description: \n In Docker vocabulary an image is a lightweight, stand-alone, executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software, including the code, a runtime, libraries, environment variables, and config files.

name.title: Docker image name.
name.description: \n To define name of docker image.

pullPolicy.title: Image pull policy.
pullPolicy.description:
\n It define the policy on how to pull the specified image during an update.
\n Its configurable values are Always, IfNotPresent and Never (Default value: IfNotPresent).

pullSecret.title: Image pull secret.
pullSecret.description: \n PullSecret field in the file specifies that API server should get the credentials from a Secret in Kubernetes cluster (Default value: awsecr-cred).

registry.title: Image registry.
registry.description: \n This defines the URL to the registry that store the application image (Default value: 461232396433.dkr.ecr.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com).

dedicatedNode.title: Dedicated Node.
dedicatedNode.description: \n Deployment on a dedicated node (pre-tainted and pre-labeled).

enabled.title: To enable deployment on a dedicated node.
enabled.description: \n To define if deployment on a dedicated node will be enabled or not (Default value: false).

nodeLabelKey.title: Cluster node label key.
nodeLabelKey.description: \n To define the key of the label applied to the dedicated node.

nodeLabelValue.title: Cluster node label value.
nodeLabelValue.description: \n To define the value of the label applied to the dedicated node.

service.title: Micro service.
service.description:
\n A micro-service is a tightly scoped, strongly encapsulated, loosely coupled, independently deployable and independently scalable application component.

\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/development-guide/configuration/helm-charts/microservice/

istio.title: Istio to handle external calls to HTTPS endpoints.
istio.description:
\n In SBCP, Istio is in charge of performing the TLS/mTLS origination and port rewriting.
\n Application pods must call a given host using plain HTTP on port 80.
\n
\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/development-guide/service-mesh/
istio.x-intellij-html-description:
In SBCP, Istio is in charge of performing the TLS/mTLS origination and port rewriting.
Application pods must call a given host using plain HTTP on port 80.

More information: Service mesh

outlierDetection.title: Outlier detection for Istio.
outlierDetection.description:
\n Outlier Detection is an Istio Resiliency strategy to detect unusual host behavior and evict the unhealthy hosts from the set of load balanced healthy hosts inside a cluster.
\n It automatically tracks the status of each individual host and checks metrics like consecutive errors and latency associated with service calls.

enabled.title: To enable Istio outlier detection.
enabled.description: \n To define if Istio outlierDetection will be enabled or not (Default value: false).

consecutiveErrors.title: To define consecutive errors for Istio outlier detection.
consecutiveErrors.description:
\n Number of errors before a host is ejected from the connection pool.
\n When the upstream host is accessed over an opaque TCP connection, connect timeouts, connection error/failure and request failure events qualify as a error (Default value: 5).

interval.title: To define interval for Istio outlier detection.
interval.description:
\n Time interval between ejection sweep analysis.
\n Format: 1h/1m/1s/1ms. MUST BE >=1ms (Default value: 10).

baseEjectionTime.title: To define base ejection time for Istio outlier detection.
baseEjectionTime.description:
\n Minimum ejection duration.
\n A host will remain ejected for a period equal to the product of minimum ejection duration and the number of times the host has been ejected.
\n This technique allows the system to automatically increase the ejection period for unhealthy upstream servers.
\n format: 1h/1m/1s/1ms. MUST BE >=1ms (Default value: 30s).

maxEjectionPercent.title: To define max ejection percent for Istio outlier detection.
maxEjectionPercent.description: \n Maximum percent of hosts in the load balancing pool for the upstream service that can be ejected (Default value: 40).

minHealthPercent.title: To define min health percent for Istio outlier detection.
minHealthPercent.description: \n Outlier detection will be enabled as long as the associated load balancing pool has at least min_health_percent hosts in healthy mode (Default value: 50).

timeout.title: Time out for Istio.
timeout.description: \n A timeout for HTTP requests can be specified using the timeout field of the route rule.

enabled.title: To enable Istio timeout.
enabled.description: \n To define if Istio retryPolicy will be enabled or not (Default value: false).

value.title: Time out for Istio.
value.description: \n To define time out value for Istio (Default value: 10).

enabled.title: To enable Istio retry.
enabled.description: \n To define if Istio retryPolicy will be enabled or not (Default value: true).

attempts.title: Number of retries to be allowed for a given request.
attempts.description:
\n The interval between retries will be determined automatically (25ms+).
\n When request timeout of the HTTP route or per_try_timeout is configured, the actual number of retries attempted also depends on the specified request timeout and per_try_timeout values (Default retry value: 2). 
\n Attempts for Retry could also be set to 0(i.e. disabled). In this case, there would be a Virtual Service created with no retry.
\n If we disable the VS, (stop the creation of VS), global setting will be applied i.e 2 retry.

perTryTimeout.title: Time out per attempt for a given request.
perTryTimeout.description: \n Including the initial call and any retries (Default value: 3)

methods.title: Restrict the methods for a given request.
methods.description: \n To restrict the methods in the regex format, not used by default.

enabled.title: To enable server-proxy Istio retry policy.
enabled.description: \n To define if Istio retryPolicy will be enabled or not for server-proxy (Default value: true).

attempts.title: Number of retries to be allowed for a given request.
attempts.description:
\n The interval between retries will be determined automatically (25ms+).
\n When request timeout of the HTTP route or per_try_timeout is configured, the actual number of retries attempted also depends on the specified request timeout and per_try_timeout values (Default retry value: 0). 
\n Attempts for Retry could also be set to 0(i.e. disabled). In this case, there would be a Virtual Service created with no retry.

perTryTimeout.title: Time out per attempt for a given request.
perTryTimeout.description: \n Including the initial call and any retries (Default value: 3)

methods.title: Restrict the methods for a given request.
methods.description: \n To restrict the methods in the regex format, not used by default.

startupProbe.title: Startup probe to watch the health state of the application.
startupProbe.description:
\n To used to know when a container application has started.
\n
\n More information: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-liveness-readiness-startup-probes/ and https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/observability/kubernetes-way/health-check/
startupProbe.x-intellij-html-description:
To used to know when a container application has started.

More information: Startup Probe and Health Check

endPoint.title: End point for startup probe.
endPoint.description:
\n To implement functional checks in an application that external tools can access through exposed endpoints at regular intervals.
\n This can help to verify that applications and services are performing correctly (Default value: /actuator/health/startup).

initialDelaySeconds.title: Initial delay seconds for startup probe.
initialDelaySeconds.description: \n Seconds to wait after the container has started (Default value: 10).

timeoutSeconds.title: Time out seconds for startup probe.

periodSeconds.title: Period seconds for startup probe.
periodSeconds.description: \n Wait time between probe executions (Default value: 5).

failureThreshold.title: Failure threshold for startup probe.
failureThreshold.description: \n Threshold needed to mark the container unhealthy (Default value: 20).

readinessProbe.title: Readiness probe to watch the health state of the application.
readinessProbe.description:

resources.title: Resource Management for Pods and Containers.
resources.description:
\n When you specify a Pod, you can optionally specify how much of each resource a container needs.
\n The most common resources to specify are CPU and memory (RAM); there are others.
\n
\n More information: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/manage-resources-containers/

cpu.description: \n To define the limit on usage of CPU resources.

memory.description: \n To define the limit on usage of memory resources.

requests.title: Request for resources.
requests.description: \n If the node where a Pod is running has enough of a resource available, it's possible (and allowed) for a container to use more resource than its request for that resource specifies.

cpu.title: Request for cpu resource.

autoscaling.title: Horizontal pod auto scaling.
autoscaling.description:
\n In order to satisfy the demand, it is possible to spread the load over several services automatically. For SBCP, the Kubernetes layer is used to manage the autoscaling of application.
\n Some recommendation for horizontal pod autoscaling: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/specifications/hpa/

enabled.title: To enable hpa.
enabled.description: \n To define if horizontal pod autoscaling will be enabled or not (Default value: true).

minReplicas.title: Minimum replicas for hpa.
minReplicas.description: \n Sets the minimum number of replicas for this Deployment (Default value: 1).

maxReplicas.title: Maximum replicas for hpa.
maxReplicas.description: \n Sets the maximum number of replicas for this Deployment (Default value: 20).

cpuPercentage.title: Cpu percentage in each pod for hpa.
cpuPercentage.description: \n Target utilization value is set so that the controller calculates the utilization value as a percentage of the equivalent resource request on the containers in each Pod (Default value: 80).

behavior.title: Scale down or scale up behavior for hpa.
behavior.description: \n To define properties for hpa behaviour like scaledown, scaleup.

scaleDown.title: Scale down to reduce resources for hpa.
scaleDown.description: \n To define scale down behaviour as demand reduces for resources or traffic reduces.

stabilizationWindowSeconds.title: Scale down instabilities of resource usage for hpa.
stabilizationWindowSeconds.description:
\n Sometimes, a process can quickly switch between big load and low load.
\n In such a case, the HPA would adapt the sizing of the application too frequently, bringing a new layer of instabilities.
\n In order to avoid that, the field stabilizationWindowSeconds can be used.
\n For scale down, it will keep the highest scale calculation from the interval to scale the application (Default value: 850).
\n
\n More Information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/development-guide/hpa/recommendations#instabilities-of-resource-usage

policies.title: Scale down policies for hpa.
policies.description:
\n In order to prevent the HPA from starting additional pods at that time, the periodSeconds field of the scaling policy should be used.
\n This field is the period of time that the HPA calculate a number of pod to scale.
\n The value corresponds approximately to the application startup time.

type.title: Scale down policy type for hpa.
type.description: \n To define HPA scale down policy type e.g. Percent, Pods.

value.title: Scale down policy value for hpa.
value.description: \n To define HPA scale down policy value.

periodSeconds.title: Period seconds for hpa scale down policy .
periodSeconds.description:
\n The periodSeconds corresponds to the computation of the number of nodes.
\n And the stabilizationWindowSeconds compare each result of periodSeconds and find the min or max of the results value list (depending of scale  up: min value) or scale  down: max value)).
\n If there are not enough calculation steps during the windows, the result may be wrong.

scaleUp.title: HPA scale up to increase resources.
scaleUp.description: \n To define scale up behaviour as demand increases for resources or traffic increases.

stabilizationWindowSeconds.title: Scale up instabilities of resource usage for hpa.
stabilizationWindowSeconds.description:
\n Sometimes, a process can quickly switch between big load and low load.
\n In such a case, the HPA would adapt the sizing of the application too frequently, bringing a new layer of instabilities.
\n In order to avoid that, the field stabilizationWindowSeconds can be used.
\n For scale up, it will keep the lower scale calculation from the interval to scale the application (Default value: 300).
\n
\n More Information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/development-guide/hpa/recommendations#instabilities-of-resource-usage

policies.title: Scale up policies for hpa.

value.title: Scale up policy value for hpa.
value.description: \n To define HPA scale up policy value .

periodSeconds.description:

\n And the stabilizationWindowSeconds compare each result of periodSeconds and find the min or max of the results value list (depending of scale  up: min value) or scale  down: max value)).
\n If there are not enough calculation steps during the windows, the result may be wrong.

configMaps.title: Content of Kubernetes configMaps generated by this chart.
configMaps.description:
\n Content of configMaps configured in configMaps keys of sbcp-spring-configuration chart.
\n Content is managed as global values to ease its configuration at higher levels of the bundle.
\n Content defined in global.spring.configMaps values is ignored if key is not defined and enabled in values of a dependent sbcp-spring-configuration chart.
\n
\n The keys in map must be valid K8S configMap names and must end with a major version: "^[a-z\d-]*-v\d+$"
\n
\n Content of each configMap is divided in 3 sections (international, localization and customization) that should be configured at different levels of the bundle.
\n The 3 sections are aggregated into a single configMap of Spring properties by the chart.
\n
\n More information: https://developers.sbcp.io/docs/current/development-guide/configuration/helm-charts/
configMaps.x-intellij-html-description:
Content of configMaps configured in configMaps values of sbcp-spring-configuration chart.
Content is managed as global values to ease its configuration at higher levels of the bundle.
Content defined in global.spring.configMaps values is ignored if key is not defined and enabled in values of a dependent sbcp-spring-configuration chart.

The keys in map must be valid K8S configMap names and must end with a major version: ^[a-z\d-]*-v\d+$

Content of each configMap is divided in 3 sections:
  • international: properties manageable by R&D only
  • localization: properties overridable by localization team
  • customization: properties manageable by project team
Each section should be configured at different levels of the bundle.
The 3 sections are aggregated into a single configMap of Spring properties by the chart.

More information: SBCP configuration guidelines

international.title: International section of the configMap.
international.description:
\n International section of configMaps should only be configured in international bundles maintained by R&D.
\n YAML format is expected as input.

localization.title: Localization section of the configMap (has precedence on international section).
localization.description:
\n Localization section of configMaps should only be configured in localization bundles maintained by PS or R&D.
\n YAML format is expected as input.

customization.title: Customization section of the configMap (has precedence on international and localization sections).
customization.description:
\n Customization section of configMaps should only be configured in customization bundles maintained by PS.
\n YAML format is expected as input.

useVersionedAppName.description: This configuration option determines whether to use a versioned application name. If set to true, the application name will include the API version as a suffix.

app.description: \n To define details for application like apiVersion, env, ports, dependencies, properties.

apiVersion.title: Major version for api of an application.
apiVersion.description:
\n API version is appended to the microservice name for all generated resources (deployment, service, autoscaler ...).
\n It defaults to v1 and allows to handle breaking changes in API exposed by a microservice.
\n By deploying the new version of the microservice in parallel with the previous version (Default value: v1).
\n
\n More information: https://docs.soprabanking.io/sbcp/latest/en/docs/specifications/versioning/rest_api_versioning/. 
\n This property is marked as Deprecated from 2025.1 final release.

provisionedResources.title: List infrastructure dependencies of the application.
provisionedResources.description: \n To define infrastructure dependencies that needs to be included for current application.

kafka.title: Represents configurations specific to Kafka services.
kafka.description:
\n This specifies the configurations related to Kafka as a messaging service.
\n It would include properties to control Kafkas behavior, such as whether it is enabled, topic settings, etc. This structure allows flexibility in toggling Kafka functionality, enabling or disabling specific topics, and applying detailed settings at the topic level.

enabled.title: A flag to indicate whether Kafka service is enabled.
enabled.description: \n Indicates whether Kafka is provisioned for this application.

topics.title: Contains configurations for Kafka topics, represented as key-value pairs.
topics.description:
\n This specifies the configurations for Kafka topics, represented as key-value pairs.
\n The key is the topic name, and the value contains specific configurations for the topic.

enabled.title: A flag to indicate whether a specific topic is enabled.
enabled.description: \n Indicates whether this topic is required by the microservice.

config.title: Holds additional configurations specific to the topic.
config.description: \n Configuration details for the Kafka topic. This is optional if the microservice is not the topic owner.

retentionTime.title: Specifies how long Kafka retains the messages in the topic before they are deleted.
retentionTime.description:
\n This specifies how long Kafka retains the messages in the topic before they are deleted.
\n Typically defined in a time format like seconds, minutes, hours, or days (ms, s, m, h, or d).

partitions.title: The number of partitions the topic should have.
partitions.description: \n This specifies the number of partitions the topic should have. It determines the parallelism and scalability of the topic.

replicationFactor.title: Defines the number of replicas for each partition.
replicationFactor.description: \n This specifies the number of replicas for each partition, ensuring fault tolerance.

cleanupPolicy.title: Determines how Kafka handles data cleanup.
cleanupPolicy.description: \n The cleanup policy for the Kafka topic. Allowed values: 'DELETE' or 'COMPACT'. Default: DELETE.

\n Log type used as an informative label named log_type in created Kubernetes objects (deployment, service, job, HPA ...).
\n It is not mandatory and does not impact the log format of the application. (Default value: sbs).
\n
\n More information: https://docs.soprabanking.io/sbcp/latest/en/docs/specifications/observability/logs/#pattern
