kind.title: The category of service provided by the application.
kind.description: \n kind used as an informative label in created Kubernetes objects (deployment, service, job, HPA ...). (Default value: argo-workflow).

retryStrategy.title: Retry Configuration for Handling retries after failures and errors
retryStrategy.description: \n The retryStrategy object defines the retry behavior, this allows to handle retries after failures and errors.

limit.title: Retry Limit.
limit.description: \n This specifies the maximum number of retries allowed for the operation

backoff.title: Retry Backoff.
backoff.description: \n This specifies the backoff strategy for retrying the operation

duration.title: Duration of the backoff
duration.description: \n This specifies the initial duration of the backoff period

factor.title: Factor of the backoff
factor.description: \n This specifies the factor by which the backoff duration increases after each retry.

maxDuration.title: Max Duration of the backoff
maxDuration.description: \n This specifies the maximum duration of the backoff period.

expression.title: Retry Expression.
expression.description: \n Specifies the expression that determines whether to retry the operation. If the expression evaluates to true, the operation will be retried.

affinity.title: Retry Affinity.
affinity.description: \n Specifies the affinity rules for retrying the operation.

retryPolicy.title: Retry Policy.
retryPolicy.description: \n Specifies the retry policy that will be used to determine when a retry should be attempted.

workflow.title: Define your Argo Workflow, cronWorkflow, EventSource and Sensor.
workflow.description:
\n Configure your helm chart with Argo specific data like setting up Workflow/cron workflow.
\n In case of on demand processing, define your eventsource, sensor and webhook details.

enabled.title: To enable workflow execution of job/cron-job.
enabled.description: \n Can be used to disable normal and cron workflows, so that only workflow template gets deployed. (Default value: true).

type.title: Used to specify a different serviceAccount.(ONLY TO BE USED BY ANALYTICS TEAM)
type.description: \n Can be used to specify a different service account for deploying on Kubernetes.

serviceAccountName.title: Specify the name of the serviceAccount.(ONLY TO BE USED BY ANALYTICS TEAM)
serviceAccountName.description: \n Specify the name of the service account for deploying on Kubernetes, (Default value: default for all teams except analytics).

archive.title: Archiving of argo workflow.
archive.description: \n If you want the argo workflow to be archived in Postgres database. Possible values: always, none

cron.title: Argo Cron enables you to schedule your batch.
cron.description: \n Argo CronWorkflow are workflows that run on a preset schedule.

concurrencyPolicy.title: Enables to set your Concurrency Policy
concurrencyPolicy.description:
\n Policy that determines what to do if multiple Workflows are scheduled at the same time. 
\n Available options: Allow: allow all, Replace: remove all old before scheduling a new, Forbid: do not allow any new while there are old

schedule.title: Schedule time at which the Workflow will be run.
schedule.description: \n User can schedule the time at which the workflow will be run automatically. (Example: "5 4 * * *").

timezone.title: Timezone for the schedule.
timezone.description: \n User can specify the timezone for the schedule. (Example: "Europe/Paris").

eventSource.title: Configure Argo Events and Sensors.
eventSource.description: \n (DEPRACATED) Enables your workflows to be trigger on demand based on Events and Sensors. This property has been marked as **deprecated** starting from version **2025.2**, and will be **removed in version 2025.4.

name.title: Name of the Event
name.description: \n Name will be used to define your name of eventSource in Argo.

port.title: Port to run HTTP server on.
port.description: \n Enables your port number for micro service to be trigger through http request.

targetPort.title: Define Target port for your micro service
targetPort.description: \n It is the port on which the service will send requests to, that your micro service will be listening on.

webhook.title: Name of webhook for your application.
webhook.description: \n Name of the webhook that you want to specify. Same name will used to create the sensor for Argo server.

replicas.title: Number of replicas for your application.
replicas.description: \n To achieve High Availability, we can set replicas values as 2. This will create 2 pods running for event source well as for sensors. Default values is 1

arguments.title: Arguments for the event source.
arguments.description: \n Arguments for the event source and sensor.

parameters.title: Parameters for the event source.
parameters.description: \n Parameters for the event source and sensor, to be passed to the workflow

traceContext.title: Trace context from the Server Argo Webhook
traceContext.description: \n Pass trace context from the Server Argo Webhook to the workflow as arguments and environment variables.

enabled.title: Enable trace context.
enabled.description: \n Enable or disable the trace context.

values.title: Trace context parameters from the Server Argo Webhook
values.description: \n Pass race context parameters from the Server Argo Webhook to the workflow as arguments and environment variables.

name.title: Name of the parameter
name.description: \n Name of the body parameter to be captured from the API request.

value.title: Value of the parameter
value.description: \n Value of the parameter to be captured from the API request.

default.title: Default value for the parameter
default.description: \n Default value to be used if not provided in the API request.

requestParameters.title: API request body parameters from the Server Argo Webhook
requestParameters.description: \n Pass body parameters from the Server Argo Webhook to the workflow as arguments and environment variables.

name.title: Name of the body parameter
name.description: \n Name of the body parameter to be captured from the API request.

value.title: Value of the body parameter
value.description: \n Value of the body parameter to be captured from the API request.

default.title: Default value for the body parameter
default.description: \n Default value to be used if not provided in the API request.

resources.title: Container resource configuration for EventSource pods
resources.description: Resource requests and limits for EventSource containers.

sensor.title: Configure Argo Sensor.
sensor.description: \n (DEPRECATED) Enables your workflows to be triggered on demand based on Events and Sensors. This property has been marked as **deprecated** starting from version **2025.2**, and will be **removed in version 2025.4**.

resources.title: Container resource configuration for Sensor pods
resources.description: Resource requests and limits for Sensor containers.

resources.title: Container resource configuration for Workflow pods
resources.description: Resource requests and limits for Workflow containers.

activeDeadlineSeconds.title: Active Deadline Seconds.
activeDeadlineSeconds.description: \n Specifies the duration in seconds that the workflow is allowed to run before being forcefully terminated.

ttlStrategy.title: Time to live strategy for the workflow.
ttlStrategy.description:
Specifies the time-to-live (TTL) strategy for the workflow.

 The TTL strategy determines how long the workflow should be retained before it is automatically terminated.

secondsAfterCompletion.title: Seconds after completion.
secondsAfterCompletion.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after the workflow has completed before it is terminated.

secondsAfterFailure.title: Seconds after failure.
secondsAfterFailure.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after the workflow has failed before it is terminated.

secondsAfterSuccess.title: Seconds after Success.
secondsAfterSuccess.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after the workflow has succeeded before it is terminated.

templateName.title: The template name for the workflow and entrypoint.
templateName.description: \n This name will be used internally to define the entrypoint of the Argo Workflow

failFast.title: Control the scheduling of new steps for DAG logic.
failFast.description:
\n The Argo DAG logic has a built-in fail fast feature to stop scheduling new steps, as soon as it detects that one of the DAG nodes has failed.
\n Then it waits until all DAG nodes are completed before failing the DAG itself (Default value: true). 
\n f set to false, it allows a DAG to run all branches of the DAG to completion (either success or failure) regardless of the failed outcomes of branches in the DAG.

dependencyBetweenBatch.title: Dependency Between Batches.
dependencyBetweenBatch.description: \n Enables your workflows to run based on another workflow status.

enabled.title: Enable dependent batch functionality in the workflow
enabled.description: \n Default value is false. If set to true, then the dependent batch functionality will be enabled, allowing the DAG to run based on the status of the dependent batch.

dependentBatchName.title: Name of the dependent batch.
dependentBatchName.description:
\n Specifies the prefix of the dependent batch name on which the DAG workflow depends. 
\n In our Argo workflows, the exact name of a batch job is not known in advance because a randomly generated suffix is appended to the workflow name (e.g., if the workflow name is `plan-aliases-aw`, Argo might run it as `plan-aliases-aw-v2jw5`). 
\n Therefore, users should provide the known prefix of the workflow name.

securityContext.title: Security context for the workflow.
securityContext.description: \n Specifies the security context for the workflow.

runAsUser.title: Run as user.
runAsUser.description: \n Specifies the user ID that runs the workflow.

runAsGroup.title: Run as group.
runAsGroup.description: \n Specifies the group ID that runs the workflow.

runAsNonRoot.title: Run as non root.
runAsNonRoot.description: \n Specifies whether the workflow runs as a non-root user.

readOnlyRootFilesystem.title: Read only root filesystem.
readOnlyRootFilesystem.description: \n Specifies whether the root filesystem is read-only.

privileged.title: Privileged.
privileged.description: \n Specifies whether the workflow runs in privileged mode.

capabilities.title: Capabilities.
capabilities.description: \n Specifies the capabilities for the workflow.

allowPrivilegeEscalation.title: Allow privilege escalation.
allowPrivilegeEscalation.description: \n Specifies whether privilege escalation is allowed.

inputParameters.title: Input parameters
inputParameters.description:
Optional map of input parameters for the template.
 Keys are used as input parameter names and must match pattern '^[a-zA-Z0-9_]+$'.

 More info: https://argo-workflows.readthedocs.io/en/latest/walk-through/parameters/
inputParameters.x-intellij-html-description:
Optional map of input parameters for the template.
Keys are used as input parameter names and must match pattern ^[a-zA-Z0-9_]+$.

More info: https://argo-workflows.readthedocs.io/en/latest/walk-through/parameters/

default.title: Default value for the input parameter
default.description: \n Default is the default value to use for an input parameter if a value was not supplied

value.title: Value for the input parameter
value.description:
\n Value is the literal value to use for the parameter.
\n If specified, the value takes precedence over any passed values

parallelism.title: Maximum number of pods running in parallel.
parallelism.description:
\n Specifies the maximum number of pods that can run in parallel for this workflow.
\n This setting overrides the default parallelism configured in the argo-workflows-workflow-controller-configmap.
\n It is not recommended to set the parallelism value higher than 10, as it may lead to resource contention or unpredictable behavior during execution. (Default value: 3)

dag.title: DAGTemplate is a template subtype for Directed Acyclic Graph(DAG) templates.
dag.description:
\n A DAG template allows you to define your tasks as a graph of dependencies.
\n In a DAG, you list all your tasks and set which other tasks must complete before a particular task can begin.
\n Tasks without any dependencies will be run immediately.

templateRef.title: Reference to the other workflow template.
templateRef.description:
\n User could specify the reference to the other workflow template that is needed for the successful deployment of workflow.
\n If templateRef is not provided, then name of DAG task would be picked as template reference name.

name.title: Name of the referred workflow template
name.description: \n Name will be used to refer to the workflow template that contains the logic of the deployment.

template.title: Name of the entrypoint for workflow
template.description:
\n Template name will be used as an entrypoint for the workflow template and it should be same as given while deploying workflow template.
\n It is an optional field, and if not provided, then default value will be picked i.e. template

dependencies.title: Specify the dependencies on other DAG task.
dependencies.description:
\n 
\n Set which other tasks must complete before a particular task can begin.
\n It is an optional field and tasks without any dependencies will be run immediately.

arguments.title: Additional arguments provided for DAG task.
arguments.description: \n User could specify the additional arguments needed for the for DAG task to run successfully.

parameters.title: Arguments list provided for DAG task
parameters.description: \n User could specify the parameters like name, value needed for the for DAG task.

enabled.title: Enable/disable the DAG task.
enabled.description:
\n 
\n It can be used to enable or disable the DAG task.
\n It is an optional field and by default it would be considered as true.
\n If a DAG task is set to false, it will dynamically remove the template name listed under the dependencies of other DAG tasks, eliminating the need for manual removal.

continueOn.title: Handle the execution of DAG task after failure or error.
continueOn.description:
\n 
\n The continueOn property allows a task to continue execution even if it fails or encounters an error.

failed.title: Continue the execution of DAG task after failure.
failed.description:
\n 
\n If set to true, the DAG task will continue execution even if it fails.

error.title: Continue the execution of DAG task after error.
error.description:
\n 
\n If set to true, the DAG task will continue execution even if it encounters an error.

when.title: Conditional execution of a DAG.
when.description:
\n 
\n The syntax is implemented by govaluate which offers the support of complex syntax.

prometheusMetrics.title: Prometheus metrics
prometheusMetrics.description:
Optional map of Prometheus metrics emitted from a workflow.
 Metrics are only emitted when batch plan is run as a workflow and not when it is integrated in another batch plan.

 Keys are used as metric names and must match pattern '^[a-zA-Z0-9_]+$'.
 Keys are also used as help doc string to ensure consistency between metrics name and help across a Kubernetes cluster.

 More info: https://argo-workflows.readthedocs.io/en/latest/metrics/#defining-metrics
prometheusMetrics.x-intellij-html-description:
Optional map of Prometheus metrics emitted from a workflow.
Metrics are only emitted when batch plan is run as a workflow and not when it is integrated in another batch plan.

Keys are used as metric names and must match pattern ^[a-zA-Z0-9_]+$.
Keys are also used as help doc string to ensure consistency between metrics name and help across a Kubernetes cluster.

More info: https://argo-workflows.readthedocs.io/en/latest/metrics/#defining-metrics

enabled.title: Enable prometheus metric in the workflow
enabled.description: \n Prometheus metric is only added in workflow if enabled is set to true.

name.title: Name of the metric
name.description:
\n Name is the name of the metric.
\n When omitted, key of prometheus metrics map is used as metric name.

when.title: Conditional statement that decides when to emit the metric

realtime.title: Emit metric in realtime
realtime.description:
\n Realtime emits this metric in real time if applicable.
\n If true, the metric is emitted as long as batch plan is pending.
\n If false, the metric is emitted only when the batch plan is completed.

labels.title: Metric labels
labels.description:
\n Optional map of metric labels
\n
\n Keys are used as label keys and must match pattern '^[a-zA-Z0-9_]+$'.
\n Values are used as label values.

image.title: Docker image.
image.description: \n In Docker vocabulary an image is a lightweight, stand-alone, executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software, including the code, a runtime, libraries, environment variables, and config files.

pullSecret.title: Image pull secret.
pullSecret.description: \n PullSecret field in the file specifies that API server should get the credentials from a Secret in kubenetes cluster (Default value: awsecr-cred).

monitoring.title: Application monitoring configuration.
monitoring.description:
\n To configure monitoring for the application using different providers like Dynatrace or Prometheus.
\n This allows you to collect metrics and monitor the health and performance of your application.

provider.title: Provider name for monitoring.
provider.description: \n To define monitoring provider name either dynatrace or prometheus. default is dynatrace (Default value: dynatrace).

dynatrace.title: Dynatrace monitoring.
dynatrace.description: \n To define properties for monitoring by dynatrace.

scrape.title: Enable scraping for dynatrace monitoring.
scrape.description: \n To define if scraping will be enabled for dynatrace monitoring.

port.title: Port for dynatrace monitoring.
port.description: \n To define port for dynatrace monitoring (Default value: 15020).

path.title: Path for dynatrace monitoring.
path.description: \n To define path for dynatrace monitoring (Default value: /stats/prometheus).

metricsFilter.title: Metrics filter for dynatrace monitoring.
metricsFilter.description: \n To define metrics filter for dynatrace monitoring.

mode.title: Mode for metrics filter.
mode.description: \n To define mode for metrics filter for dynatrace monitoring (Default value: include).

names.title: Metrics names for filtering.
names.description: \n To define list of metric names for dynatrace monitoring filtering.

argo.title: Global Switch to enable/disable Argo.
argo.description: \n We can enable/disable Argo using this property for the whole bundle.

enabled.title: Enabling/Disabling Argo.
enabled.description: \n We can enable/disable Argo using this property. On premise deliveries can disable it.

image.title: Docker Image.
image.description: \n Docker image is a lightweight, stand-alone, executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software, including the code, a runtime, libraries, environment variables, and config files.

registry.title: Image registry.
registry.description: \n This defines the URL to the registry that store the application image (Default value: 461232396433.dkr.ecr.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com).

pullSecret.title: Image pull secret.
pullSecret.description: \n PullSecret field in the file specifies that API server should get the credentials from a Secret in kubenetes cluster (Default value: awsecr-cred).

operators.title: Database operators.
operators.description:
\n An operator is a reserved word or a character that is used to query our database in a SQL expression.
\n Operators are necessary to define a condition in SQL, as they act as a connector between two or more conditions.
\n Any given application SHALL NOT use more than one database for each database type (one in MongoDB + one in PostgreSQL).
\n Any given database SHALL NOT be used by more than one application.
\n
\n More information: https://docs.soprabanking.io/sbcp/latest/en/docs/specifications/database-management/
operators.x-intellij-html-description:
An operator is a reserved word or a character that is used to query our database in a SQL expression.
Operators are necessary to define a condition in SQL, as they act as a connector between two or more conditions.
Any given application SHALL NOT use more than one database for each database type (one in MongoDB + one in PostgreSQL).
Any given database SHALL NOT be used by more than one application.

More information: Database Management

priorityClass.title: Priority Class.
priorityClass.description:
\n Priority Class is a resource that defines a scheduling priority for pods.
\n Priority Class is defined by specifying a value and a globalDefault flag.

\n More information: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/pod-priority-preemption/

apiVersion.title: Major version for api of an application.
apiVersion.description:
\n API version is appended to the microservice name for all generated resources (deployment, service, autoscaler ...).
\n It defaults to v1 and allows to handle breaking changes in API exposed by a microservice.
\n By deploying the new version of the microservice in parallel with the previous version (Default value: v1).
\n
\n More information: https://docs.soprabanking.io/sbcp/latest/en/docs/specifications/versioning/rest_api_versioning/. 
\n This property is marked as Deprecated from 2025.1 final release.

env.title: Environment properties.
env.description:
\n Environment properties hold the user or system defined dependent variables.
\n It hold values for variables, extraConfigMaps.

vars.title: Environment variables.
vars.description:
\n Environment variable hold the user or system defined dependent variables that are required to run the micro service that run with in the application pod.
\n Env vars are easy to change between deploys without changing any code; unlike config files, there is little chance of them being checked into the code repo accidentally; and unlike custom config files, or other config mechanisms such as Java System Properties, they are a language and OS-agnostic standard.

extraEnv.title: Extra environment variables.
extraEnv.description:
\n Extra environment variable hold the user or system defined dependent variables that are required to run the micro service that run with in the application pod.
\n Env vars are easy to change between deploys without changing any code; unlike config files, there is little chance of them being checked into the code repo accidentally; and unlike custom config files, or other config mechanisms such as Java System Properties, they are a language and OS-agnostic standard.

extraConfigMaps.title: Additional config maps for environment.
extraConfigMaps.description:
\n ConfigMap is used to store non-confidential data in key-value pairs.
\n ConfigMap allows to decouple environment-specific configuration from your application pod, so that your applications are easily portable.

enabled.title: Enable creation of the additional config map.
enabled.description: \n Value should be true by default and can be set to false in parent charts to disable generation of the configMap.

dynamicExtraConfigMaps.title: Additional config maps(with dynamic name) for environment.
dynamicExtraConfigMaps.description:

enabled.title: Enable creation of the additional config map.
enabled.description: \n Value should be true by default and can be set to false in parent charts to disable generation of the configMap.

encrypted.title: Encryption for secrets at environment level.
encrypted.description:
\n Secrets MUST NOT be stored in source management system (likeGit).
\n  If secrets have to be stored in Git, an encryption mechanism must be put in place, and the decryption material must be stored in a separate place outside the Git project.

namespaceWide.title: To define encryption scope under namespace.
namespaceWide.description: \n Allows specifying whether the encryption scope of the SealedSecret-encrypted values is namespace-wide or not (Default value: true).

vars.title: Encryption vars.
vars.description:
\n Key-value pairs of environment variables to be made available to the micro-service, where the key is the env var name, and the value is the SealedSecret-encrypted value.
\n
\n More information: https://docs.soprabanking.io/sbcp/latest/en/docs/development-guide/environment/deploy-secret/

provisionedResources.title: Provisioned Resources Configuration.
provisionedResources.description: \n A collection of infrastructure resources explicitly allocated for the application, including messaging, databases, storage, and other external dependencies.

kafka.title: Represents configurations specific to Kafka services.
kafka.description:
\n This specifies the configurations related to Kafka as a messaging service.
\n It would include properties to control Kafkas behavior, such as whether it is enabled, topic settings, etc. This structure allows flexibility in toggling Kafka functionality, enabling or disabling specific topics, and applying detailed settings at the topic level.

enabled.title: A flag to indicate whether Kafka service is enabled.
enabled.description: \n Indicates whether Kafka is provisioned for this application.

topics.title: Contains configurations for Kafka topics, represented as key-value pairs.
topics.description:
\n This specifies the configurations for Kafka topics, represented as key-value pairs.
\n The key is the topic name, and the value contains specific configurations for the topic.

enabled.title: A flag to indicate whether a specific topic is enabled.
enabled.description: \n Indicates whether this topic is required by the microservice.

config.title: Holds additional configurations specific to the topic.
config.description: \n Configuration details for the Kafka topic. This is optional if the microservice is not the topic owner.

retentionTime.title: Specifies how long Kafka retains the messages in the topic before they are deleted.
retentionTime.description:
\n This specifies how long Kafka retains the messages in the topic before they are deleted.
\n Typically defined in a time format like seconds, minutes, hours, or days (ms, s, m, h, or d).

partitions.title: The number of partitions the topic should have.
partitions.description: \n This specifies the number of partitions the topic should have. It determines the parallelism and scalability of the topic.

replicationFactor.title: Defines the number of replicas for each partition.
replicationFactor.description: \n This specifies the number of replicas for each partition, ensuring fault tolerance.

cleanupPolicy.title: Determines how Kafka handles data cleanup.
cleanupPolicy.description: \n The cleanup policy for the Kafka topic. Allowed values: 'DELETE' or 'COMPACT'. Default: DELETE.

exposition.title: Exposition configuration(mTLS), This object is optional in case the topic needs to be exposed to external users.
exposition.description: \n Exposition configuration(mTLS), This object is optional in case the topic needs to be exposed to external users.

enabled.title: A flag to indicate whether a mTLS is enabled.
enabled.description: \n A flag to indicate whether a mTLS is enabled.

users.description: List of users with their subjects and permissions.

subject.title: The subject of the user.
subject.description: By default, the name of the principal identified by a TLS certificate is the DN (X.500 Distinguished Name) of the certificate. Please refer to [TLS principal user name](https://docs.confluent.io/platform/current/security/authorization/acls/overview.html#tls-principal-user-name) documentation for more information.

permissions.title: List of permissions for the user.
permissions.description: List of permissions for the user.

retryStrategy.title: Retry Configuration for Handling retries after failures and errors
retryStrategy.description: \n The retryStrategy object defines the retry behavior, this allows to handle retries after failures and errors.

limit.title: Retry Limit.
limit.description: \n This specifies the maximum number of retries allowed for the operation

backoff.title: Retry Backoff.
backoff.description: \n This specifies the backoff strategy for retrying the operation

duration.title: Duration of the backoff
duration.description: \n This specifies the initial duration of the backoff period

factor.title: Factor of the backoff
factor.description: \n This specifies the factor by which the backoff duration increases after each retry.

maxDuration.title: Max Duration of the backoff
maxDuration.description: \n This specifies the maximum duration of the backoff period.

expression.title: Retry Expression.
expression.description: \n Specifies the expression that determines whether to retry the operation. If the expression evaluates to true, the operation will be retried.

affinity.title: Retry Affinity.
affinity.description: \n Specifies the affinity rules for retrying the operation.

retryPolicy.title: Retry Policy.
retryPolicy.description: \n Specifies the retry policy that will be used to determine when a retry should be attempted.

workflow.title: Define your Argo Workflow, cronWorkflow, EventSource and Sensor.
workflow.description:
\n Configure your helm chart with Argo specific data like setting up Workflow/cron workflow.
\n In case of on demand processing, define your eventsource, sensor and webhook details.

enabled.title: To enable workflow execution of job/cron-job.
enabled.description: \n Can be used to disable normal and cron workflows, so that only workflow template gets deployed. (Default value: true).

type.title: Used to specify a different serviceAccount.(ONLY TO BE USED BY ANALYTICS TEAM)
type.description: \n Can be used to specify a different service account for deploying on Kubernetes.

command.title: Command to be be passed in Docker image.(ONLY TO BE USED BY ANALYTICS TEAM)
command.description: \n Default command that can be passed while running a docker container.

args.title: Argument to be passed with command.(ONLY TO BE USED BY ANALYTICS TEAM)
args.description: \n Sets default parameters that can be passed to container with command

serviceAccountName.title: Specify the name of the serviceAccount.
serviceAccountName.description:
\n Specify the name of the service account for pods started by the workflow.
\n Default value: <namespace>-argo-workflow.

inputParam.description:
\n You can specify your argo template with an input parameter that is passed as the args to your command.
\n
\n Deprecated: use workflow.inputParameters instead.

priorityClassName.title: Specify the priority class name.
priorityClassName.description: \n Specify the priority class name for pods started by the workflow.

ttlStrategy.title: Time to live strategy for the workflow.
ttlStrategy.description:
Specifies the time-to-live (TTL) strategy for the workflow.

 The TTL strategy determines how long the workflow should be retained before it is automatically terminated.

secondsAfterCompletion.title: Seconds after completion.
secondsAfterCompletion.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after the workflow has completed before it is terminated.

secondsAfterFailure.title: Seconds after failure.
secondsAfterFailure.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after the workflow has failed before it is terminated.

secondsAfterSuccess.title: Seconds after Success.
secondsAfterSuccess.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after the workflow has succeeded before it is terminated.

securityContext.title: Security context for the workflow.
securityContext.description: \n Specifies the security context for the workflow.

runAsUser.title: Run as user.
runAsUser.description: \n Specifies the user ID that runs the workflow.

runAsGroup.title: Run as group.
runAsGroup.description: \n Specifies the group ID that runs the workflow.

runAsNonRoot.title: Run as non root.
runAsNonRoot.description: \n Specifies whether the workflow runs as a non-root user.

readOnlyRootFilesystem.title: Read only root filesystem.
readOnlyRootFilesystem.description: \n Specifies whether the root filesystem is read-only.

privileged.title: Privileged.
privileged.description: \n Specifies whether the workflow runs in privileged mode.

capabilities.title: Capabilities.
capabilities.description: \n Specifies the capabilities for the workflow.

allowPrivilegeEscalation.title: Allow privilege escalation.
allowPrivilegeEscalation.description: \n Specifies whether privilege escalation is allowed.

activeDeadlineSeconds.title: Active Deadline Seconds.
activeDeadlineSeconds.description: \n Specifies the number of seconds after which the workflow is terminated.

inputParameters.title: Input parameters
inputParameters.description:
Optional map of input parameters for the template.
 Keys are used as input parameter names and must match pattern '^[a-zA-Z0-9_]+$'.

 More info: https://argo-workflows.readthedocs.io/en/latest/walk-through/parameters/
inputParameters.x-intellij-html-description:

default.title: Default value for the input parameter
default.description: \n Default is the default value to use for an input parameter if a value was not supplied

value.title: Value for the input parameter
value.description:
\n Value is the literal value to use for the parameter.
\n If specified, the value takes precedence over any passed values

value.title: Value for the input parameter
value.description: \n Value is the literal value to use for the parameter.

valueFrom.description: \n ValueFrom describes a location in which to obtain the value to a parameter

prometheusTemplateMetrics.title: Prometheus template metrics
prometheusTemplateMetrics.description:
Optional map of Prometheus metrics emitted from a template.
 Template metrics are emitted when batch is run as a standalone batch or when it is integrated in a batch plan.

 Keys are used as metric names and must match pattern '^[a-zA-Z0-9_]+$'.
 Keys are also used as help doc string to ensure consistency between metrics name and help across a Kubernetes cluster.

 More info: https://argo-workflows.readthedocs.io/en/latest/metrics/#defining-metrics
prometheusTemplateMetrics.x-intellij-html-description:
Optional map of Prometheus metrics emitted from a template.
Template metrics are emitted when batch is run as a standalone batch or when it is integrated in a batch plan.

Keys are used as metric names and must match pattern ^[a-zA-Z0-9_]+$.
Keys are also used as help doc string to ensure consistency between metrics name and help across a Kubernetes cluster.

More info: https://argo-workflows.readthedocs.io/en/latest/metrics/#defining-metrics

enabled.title: Enable prometheus metric in the template
enabled.description: \n Prometheus metric is only added in template if enabled is set to true.

name.title: Name of the metric
name.description:
\n Name is the name of the metric.
\n When omitted, key of prometheus metrics map is used as metric name.

when.title: Conditional statement that decides when to emit the metric

realtime.title: Emit metric in realtime
realtime.description:
\n Realtime emits this metric in real time if applicable.
\n If true, the metric is emitted as long as batch is pending.
\n If false, the metric is emitted only when the batch is completed.

labels.title: Metric labels
labels.description:
\n Optional map of metric labels
\n
\n Keys are used as label keys and must match pattern '^[a-zA-Z0-9_]+$'.
\n Values are used as label values.

extraConfig.title: Specify Additional volumes and volumeMount for non spring batches.
extraConfig.description: \n Can be used to Specify Additional volumes and volumeMount for non spring batches.

volumes.title: Specify Additional volumes.
volumes.description:
Volume represents a directory with data that is accessible across multiple containers in a Pod.
\n The container data in a Pod is deleted or lost when a container crashes or restarts, but when you use a volume, the new container can pick up the data at the state before the container crashes.
\n The volume outlives the containers in a Pod and can be consumed by any number of containers within that Pod. 
\n
\n More information: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/

volumeMounts.title: Specify Additional volumeMounts.
volumeMounts.description:
VolumeMount entails mounting of the declared volume into a container in the same Pod.
\n This is the path in the container on which the mounting will take place.
\n Volume and volumeMounts go hand in hand.
\n You can not create a volume without mounting it or mount a volume that has not been created.

dynamicVolumes.title: Specify additional volumes with dynamic name of configmap.
dynamicVolumes.description:
Can be used to specify volumes with dynamic name of configmap. Volume represents a directory with data that is accessible across multiple containers in a Pod.
\n The container data in a Pod is deleted or lost when a container crashes or restarts, but when you use a volume, the new container can pick up the data at the state before the container crashes.
\n The volume outlives the containers in a Pod and can be consumed by any number of containers within that Pod. 
\n
\n More information: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/

dynamicVolumeMounts.title: Specify additional volumeMounts with dynamic name of configmap.
dynamicVolumeMounts.description:
Can be used to specify volumeMounts with dynamic name of configmap. VolumeMount entails mounting of the declared volume into a container in the same Pod.
\n This is the path in the container on which the mounting will take place.
\n Volume and volumeMounts go hand in hand.
\n You can not create a volume without mounting it or mount a volume that has not been created.

cpu.title: Limit on cpu resource.
cpu.description: \n To define the limit on usage of CPU resources.

memory.title: Limit on memory resource.
memory.description: \n To define the limit on usage of memory resources.

requests.title: Request for resources.
requests.description: \n If the node where a Pod is running has enough of a resource available, it's possible (and allowed) for a container to use more resource than its request for that resource specifies.

cpu.title: Request for cpu resource.
cpu.description: \n To define request for cpu resource.

memory.title: Request for memory resource.
memory.description: \n To define request for memory resource.

cron.title: Argo Cron enables you to schedule your batch.
cron.description: \n Argo CronWorkflow are workflows that run on a preset schedule.

concurrencyPolicy.title: Enables to set your Concurrency Policy
concurrencyPolicy.description:
\n Policy that determines what to do if multiple Workflows are scheduled at the same time. 
\n Available options: Allow: allow all, Replace: remove all old before scheduling a new, Forbid: do not allow any new while there are old

schedule.title: Schedule time at which the Workflow will be run.
schedule.description: \n User can schedule the time at which the workflow will be run automatically. (Example: "5 4 * * *").

timezone.title: Timezone for the schedule.
timezone.description: \n User can specify the timezone for the schedule. (Example: "Europe/Paris").

eventSource.title: Configure Argo Events and Sensors.
eventSource.description: \n (DEPRACATED) Enables your workflows to be trigger on demand based on Events and Sensors. This property has been marked as **deprecated** starting from version **2025.2**, and will be **removed in version 2025.4.

name.title: Name of the Event
name.description: \n Name will be used to define your name of eventSource in Argo.

port.title: Port to run HTTP server on.
port.description: \n Enables your port number for micro service to be trigger through http request.

targetPort.title: Define Target port for your micro service
targetPort.description: \n It is the port on which the service will send requests to, that your micro service will be listening on.

webhook.title: Name of webhook for your application.
webhook.description: \n Name of the webhook that you want to specify. Same name will used to create the sensor for Argo server.

replicas.title: Number of replicas for your application.
replicas.description: \n To achieve High Availability, we can set replicas values as 2. This will create 2 pods running for event source well as for sensors. Default values is 1

arguments.title: Arguments for the event source.
arguments.description: \n Arguments for the event source and sensor.

parameters.title: Parameters for the event source.
parameters.description: \n Parameters for the event source and sensor, to be passed to the workflow

traceContext.title: Trace context from the Server Argo Webhook
traceContext.description: \n Pass trace context from the Server Argo Webhook to the workflow as arguments and environment variables.

enabled.title: Enable trace context.
enabled.description: \n Enable or disable the trace context.

values.title: Trace context parameters from the Server Argo Webhook
values.description: \n Pass race context parameters from the Server Argo Webhook to the workflow as arguments and environment variables.

name.title: Name of the parameter
name.description: \n Name of the body parameter to be captured from the API request.

value.title: Value of the parameter
value.description: \n Value of the parameter to be captured from the API request.

default.title: Default value for the parameter
default.description: \n Default value to be used if not provided in the API request.

requestParameters.title: API request body parameters from the Server Argo Webhook
requestParameters.description: \n Pass body parameters from the Server Argo Webhook to the workflow as arguments and environment variables.

name.title: Name of the body parameter
name.description: \n Name of the body parameter to be captured from the API request.

value.title: Value of the body parameter
value.description: \n Value of the body parameter to be captured from the API request.

default.title: Default value for the body parameter
default.description: \n Default value to be used if not provided in the API request.

templateName.title: The template name for the workflow and entrypoint.
templateName.description: \n This name will be used internally to define the entrypoint of the Argo Workflow

outputs.title: Outputs of workflow
outputs.description: \n Define the `outputs` property for the workflow template.

artifacts.title: Artifacts for the workflow.
artifacts.description: \n The Artifacts files that are produced by a workflow and must be pushed to the AWS S3 Bucket.

name.title: Name of the artifact.
name.description: \n Name to be given to the artifact file, before publishing to S3 Bucket.

path.title: Path of the artifact.
path.description: \n Path of the artifact that is produced by the workflow.

image.title: Docker image.
image.description: \n In Docker vocabulary an image is a lightweight, stand-alone, executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software, including the code, a runtime, libraries, environment variables, and config files.

name.title: Docker image name.
name.description: \n To define name of docker image.

version.title: Docker image version.
version.description: \n To define version of docker image.

pullPolicy.title: Image pull policy.
pullPolicy.description:
\n It define the policy on how to pull the specified image during an update.
\n Its configurable values are Always, IfNotPresent and Never (Default value: IfNotPresent).

pullSecret.title: Image pull secret.
pullSecret.description: \n PullSecret field in the file specifies that API server should get the credentials from a Secret in kubenetes cluster (Default value: awsecr-cred).

registry.title: Image registry.
registry.description: \n This defines the URL to the registry that store the application image (Default value: 461232396433.dkr.ecr.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com).

monitoring.title: Application monitoring configuration.
monitoring.description:
\n To configure monitoring for the application using different providers like Dynatrace or Prometheus.
\n This allows you to collect metrics and monitor the health and performance of your application.

provider.title: Provider name for monitoring.
provider.description: \n To define monitoring provider name either dynatrace or prometheus. default is dynatrace (Default value: dynatrace).

dynatrace.title: Dynatrace monitoring.
dynatrace.description: \n To define properties for monitoring by dynatrace.

scrape.title: Enable scraping for dynatrace monitoring.
scrape.description: \n To define if scraping will be enabled for dynatrace monitoring.

port.title: Port for dynatrace monitoring.
port.description: \n To define port for dynatrace monitoring (Default value: 15020).

path.title: Path for dynatrace monitoring.
path.description: \n To define path for dynatrace monitoring (Default value: /stats/prometheus).

metricsFilter.title: Metrics filter for dynatrace monitoring.
metricsFilter.description: \n To define metrics filter for dynatrace monitoring.

mode.title: Mode for metrics filter.
mode.description: \n To define mode for metrics filter for dynatrace monitoring (Default value: include).

names.title: Metrics names for filtering.
names.description: \n To define list of metric names for dynatrace monitoring filtering.

prometheus.title: Prometheus monitoring.
prometheus.description: \n To define properties for monitoring by prometheus.

scrape.title: Enable scraping for prometheus monitoring.
scrape.description: \n To define if scraping will be enabled for prometheus monitoring.

port.title: Port for prometheus monitoring.
port.description: \n To define port for prometheus monitoring (Default value: 15020).

path.title: Path for prometheus monitoring.
path.description: \n To define path for prometheus monitoring (Default value: /stats/prometheus).

helm-values.json.title: Helm values for version 1.0.60 of commons-training-properties service

commons-training-properties-v1.title: Helm configuration for version 1.0.60 of commons-training-properties service
commons-training-properties-v1.description: \n Configuration deployed in commons-training-properties-v1 configMap and loaded by all services using commons-training-properties

customization.title: Customization section (has precedence on international and localization)
